data.text: Contents
Purpose

The purpose of this policy is to ensure the safety of all infants, children & young people across Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust by providing a framework for assessing, recognising and responding to acutely ill patients.

The policy provides a clear procedure for all Trust staff in the assessment and recording of patient observations and the use of Children's Early Warning Tool (CEWT) system, for all children and young people across the Trust.
Background

There is good evidence from the literature to suggest that many patients having cardiac arrest in hospital show premonitory signs for many hours before they arrest (NPSA 2007). By identifying the early signs of patient deterioration, staff will have the opportunity to intervene before cardiac arrest.
Clinical observations provide information about the child's condition to aid diagnosis, guide treatment and evaluate trends in their clinical condition.

A report by the Confidential Enquiry into Maternal and Child Health, Why Children die: a pilot study 2006 (2008) identified the need for health professionals to identify a sick child and promoted the awareness and use of early warning scoring systems.

Early warning tools are designed to detect deterioration in the physiological status of patients and to alert staff to take appropriate action. Observations which are outside normal parameters are allocated a point, which are then added to give a score. This score provides a mechanism to trigger early intervention and initiation of treatment. These are referred to as a ‘Physiological Track and Trigger' systems (NICE, 2007)
Scope
This policy applies to all infants, children and young people (up to their th birthday) admitted to the Trust.
Throughout this document, infants, children and young people are referred to as children.
All Healthcare Professionals working within the Trust must adhere to this policy. This includes all medical staff, all registered nurses, healthcare assistants (HCA), and student nurses.
Roles and responsibilities
Managing Director

The Managing Director is responsible for ensuring that processes are in place for the assessment and recording of patient observations that facilitate the early recognition of patients at risk of deterioration. This responsibility is delegated to the Medical Director and the Director of Nursing.
Medical Director and Director of Nursing
The Medical Director and Director of Nursing are responsible for ensuring that systems are in place to support the implementation of this policy.
Associate Directors of Nursing and Clinical Directors
The Associate Directors of Nursing and Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems are in place to support the implementation of this policy.
Medical and Nursing Staff
It is the responsibility of the registered nurse designated to the patient to ensure that observations are undertaken and documented in accordance with this policy.

Medical staff and registered nurses can delegate the task of undertaking observations to competent staff (including students). Once the observations have been undertaken, medical staff and registered nurses are responsible for ensuring timely interpretation of the observations and consequences of decisions made.

Once the Trust's Children's Early Warning Tool (CEWT) trigger process is activated, it is the responsibility of the registered nurse and medical staff to ensure compliance with the escalation process.
In line with all Trust policies, a breach in policy will be acted upon in accordance with appropriate professional Codes of Practice and the disciplinary process may be invoked.
Senior sisters/Charge Nurses, Matrons and Department Managers

Ensure that all patients admitted to the Trust will have their physiological observations recorded on the appropriate colour-coded age specific Children's Observation chart and their CEWT score recorded.
Ensure that staff attend all relevant mandatory training
Ensure adequate stocks of equipment required to undertake patient observations are maintained.

The lead nurses will review relevant information from audits and develop action plans to ensure improvements in compliance with the policy and inform the training and education agenda to develop skills and abilities of staff in delivering high quality care.
Deteriorating Patient / Sepsis Steering Group (DPG)

The Trust's Deteriorating Patient and Sepsis Group (DPG) is responsible for all resuscitation issues within the hospital including the regular review of the NEWS and CEWT system. This will include review of the audit findings.
The Deteriorating Patient / Sepsis Group is a sub group of the Patient Safety Group and will report to the Integrated Governance Committee and to the Patient Safety Group.
Children's Urgent and Emergency Group

The Trust's Children's Urgent and Emergency Group is responsible for monitoring issues relating to children including the CEWT system. This includes review of audit findings and reporting to the Trust's Deteriorating Patient Group.
Definitions

data.text: Monitoring and observations
One of the Trust's colour coded, age specific, Children's Observation Charts should be used for recording all children's observations and CEWT Scores.
CEWT scores should be calculated and recorded on every set of observations.
A systematic and holistic approach should be adopted when assessing, measuring and recording vital signs.
Vital signs are defined as temperature, heart/pulse rate, respiratory rate and effort and blood pressure.

Broader observations including visual inspection (general appearance), palpation (touch) and olfactory stimulus (smell) (RCN 2011) should be used in conjunction with and never separate to recording vital signs.

In addition the assessment of health should include listening, communicating (observing both verbal and non-verbal cues) and noting the child's interaction and reaction to its physical surroundings (Aylott 2006). This includes taking note of the view of parents/carers.

table_items.text: It is essential that each of the following observations are recorded as a baseline as indicated on the Children & young people (CYP) Vital Signs Observation chart

Blood pressure (where indicated) Heart Rate Central capillary refill time Respiratory rate Temperature Oxygen saturation (in air or oxygen) Conscious level (See Section 7.2) CEWT score Urine Output (where indicated) Pain, nausea and sedation score (where indicated)
The following additional observations can also be required following patient assessment and specific patient presentation

Oxygen requirement Glasgow coma score (GCS) [if head injury suspected or reduced level of consciousness] Bedside Blood glucose [confused, altered level of consciousness, diabetic, drug / drink overdose; all resus patients] Peak flow [where indicated] (teaching technique) Four limb blood pressure (cardiac congenital abnormalities) Urinalysis [confused, unconscious, diabetic patients, unexplained vomiting, suspected UTI} Pregnancy test [menstruating females] Neurovascular observations [vascular problems/limb trauma/fractures)] Visual Acuity [all eye related problems] Hearing tests Weight Height (where indicated)

data.text: Process
All children admitted to hospital should have a full assessment of the essential observations undertaken by a qualified nurse within 1 hour of admission.

The frequency of vital signs assessment (observations) should be recorded in the text section of the Children's Observation Chart and updated as the patient's clinical condition dictates. Any changes to the frequency of observations must be recorded in the allocated space. The frequency will be determined by registered nurses in consultation with medical staff. A full assessment of vital signs is required twelve hourly as a minimum (NICE, 2007).

table_items.text: Or More frequently where clinically indicated

data.text: Where a clinical decision has been made that daily observations are appropriate, this must be clearly documented on the observation chart. For those children who have palliative care needs discontinuing observations may be appropriate because they are deemed too intrusive. This should be agreed in consultation with the medical staff and parents.

Where a patient has refused vital signs assessment despite an explanation being given, the registered nurse should inform medical staff to determine whether non- compliance may be attributed to an underlying medical condition. Any action taken must be recorded on the Children's Observation Chart and documented also in the nursing documentation.

Where children are admitted for conditions and procedures supported by local or national protocols such as blood transfusion, head injury or post-operative management, the nurse should perform observations at the intervals described within the protocol.
The nurse undertaking the child's observation and recording them on the observation chart should record their initials in the box at the top of the chart.
Use of children's early warning tool
The Trust has made the decision to use four colour-coded age specific charts

The purpose of CEWT Scoring is to support HCA's and nursing staff in monitoring the condition of patients so that failure in treatment or acute deterioration because of clinical complication is promptly and appropriately managed by the medical team.

It is designed to support decision making, not replace it. If a nurse thinks that the doctor should see a patient, their expert view should over-ride the CEWT score. It is not designed to be scientifically exact; it is a quick assessment tool and as such will not be flawless.
The CEWT can be used in two ways:
As a triggering system, where a single score highlights a problem and demands an action
As a tracking system, where scores over a period of time can be used to follow a child's progress or response to treatment
How does the scoring system work?
Each child is assessed in relation to 6 core parameters which are:
Doctor/nurse/family concern
Respiratory rate
Respiratory distress
Oxygen requirement
Heart rate
Conscious level
The total CEWT score = the number of entries of shaded boxes
The assigned action will be according to the CEWT score and is described in the escalation aid found on the reverse side of the children's observation chart.
CEWT Escalation Pathway
(please refer to Appendix 2)
If the assessment has been delegated, the registered nurse responsible for the patient must be informed when the CEWT Score is 1 or above.
If the CEWT score is 2 inform the nurse in charge, continue with routine care, and perform observations as per guidelines or as directed by registered nurse.

If the CEWT score is 3 the registered nurse responsible for the patient must assess the patient, inform the nurse in charge and increase the frequency of observations and CEWT scoring. Saturation monitoring should be started if previous observations did not include them. A doctor must review the child. The SHO should review the patient within 20 minutes and the registrar should be informed and assess the child within 1 hour.

If the CEWT score is 4 the registered nurse responsible for the patient must assess the patient, inform the nurse in charge, increase the frequency of observations to hourly, commence saturation, cardiac and BP (if indicated) monitoring if not previously started. A doctor must review the child. The registrar should review

within 20 minutes and re-review within 1 hour if required. It may be appropriate to involve the consultant if the patient is still triggering after 1 hour or immediately if clinical indication to do so.

If the CEWT score is 5 or 6, the child must be reviewed by a registrar immediately. Inform the nurse in charge, continue recording observations and increase frequency to every 30 minutes, commence saturation, cardiac and BP monitoring if not previously started. Review airway, breathing, circulation, oxygen, medication, history, notes and charts
Any CEWT score of 3 or more should be recorded on the reverse side of the observation chart as part of the escalation process.

The registrar is responsible for identifying a clear medical management plan or seeking advice from appropriate senior medical staff. Once the patient is reviewed, the management plan must be documented and communicated by the medical staff to the nursing staff looking after the patient. The consultant should be informed if required and review by the anaesthetic team may be considered.

If the SHO/registrar doctor does not respond, the registered nurse responsible for the patient may contact the consultant in accordance with the escalation process. (See appendix 1). If a review is not actioned within the specified time frames, this should be documented on the escalation response documentation.
Any patient with a CEWT Score of greater than 3 or where there is senior nurse concern should have a clearly documented medical management plan which includes the required frequency of observations.

It may be appropriate to re-set the CEWT “triggers” to a different level where maximal treatment is already in place. A trigger reset should be undertaken jointly by medical staff and the senior nurse in the relevant clinical area. It should only be done when treatment for the physiological markers triggering a high score are maximally treated. This decision should be documented in the patient's notes.

CEWT Score escalation and DNAR (Do Not Attempt Resuscitation) orders may be appropriately used together. A patient who is not for resuscitation may suffer complications that will require treatment. For some patients with a DNAR order in place, CEWT Scoring may be inappropriate. Refer to the Children's DNAR Policy for further guidance if required.
Referral of a patient to a paediatric intensive care area should be made via the Children's Acute Transfer Service (CATS).
Transfer of children either inter hospital or intra hospital will follow the Transfer of Children Guideline. The STOPP tool must be used to ensure safe transfer of patient.
Guidance notes for CYP vital signs observation chart
Any deteriorating trend in physiological parameters should be regarded with suspicion.
For children with chronic illness chronically deranged physiology may be appropriate for that individual, but changes in physiological markers may be highly significant.
The charts are designed for children only (up to th birthday). A NEWS system has been devised for use with adults. Refer to the Adult Patient Observation Policy for further information.
The same chart should be used throughout the admission.
Frequency of vital sign observations and name of ward should be completed.
The demographic data (Patient Name, DOB, Hospital/NHS Number) must be documented on each chart.
When a child has a CEWT score of 3 or more or senior nurse concern then escalation should be made and a record of the call made on the reverse side of the observation chart.
Respiratory rate should be plotted on the chart as a dot.
Heart rate must be plotted on the chart as a dot.
Blood pressure should not be charted numerically but as markers ↕.
The Pain, Sedation and Nausea scores are all recorded numerically.
Weight must be recorded on admission. The frequency for further weight assessment must be documented.
Not all patients require regular blood sugar monitoring. Individual assessment is required by the medical staff/registered nurse. Where Blood Sugar monitoring is indicated, this must be documented.
The assessment of pain, sedation and nausea should be recorded routinely numerically on the Children's Observation chart.
There is a separate chart available for recording Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) if neurological observations are required.
Separate Children's Fluid Balance charts are available in clinical areas.
Medical records
All Children's Observation charts should be filed within the patient's health records when completely filled in or the patient no longer requires assessment; or at discharge or death.

The DNAR form must be stored in the patient's health records behind the patient identification sheet in the section reserved for DNR/ Advanced Directive/Preferred Pathway of Care. It is the responsibility of the originator to fix the DNR Form in to the health records so that they can be easily accessible in the event of a cardiac arrest; an alert sticker must also be put onto the outside cover of the notes. These forms are carbonised and the bottom copy should be sent to the Resuscitation Department for audit purposes.
In line with the Trust's Records Management Strategy, all patients' medical records will be managed confidentially at all times and stored securely.
All movement of patient records will be accurately tracked in accordance with the Trust's Case note Tracking Policy.
Equipment
The equipment required to undertake and carry out the observations referred to within this policy includes:
An automatic non-invasive blood pressure recording machine
A manual sphygmomanometer and stethoscope
Blood pressure cuffs (various sizes)
Pulse oximetry leads
A urinalysis machine or testing strips
Blood glucose monitoring equipment
Ketones monitoring equipment
A pen torch
A thermometer
A peak flow recorder
Weighing scales
ECG Machine
Ophthalmoscope

It is the responsibility of the ward managers to ensure adequate equipment / resources, as set out in section 10.1 are available and if not, this should be escalated to the general manager for the service. Out of hours this should be escalated to the on-call manager / service coordinator.

It is the responsibility of the ward managers to ensure that, in liaison with their manager, funds are kept available to repair / maintain, or purchase equipment, so safe levels of equipment listed in section 10.1 are available to nursing staff. This must be in conjunction with Biomedical Engineering Services (BME).
Training requirements
In accordance with the Trust's Training Needs Analysis (Mandatory Training Policy), all Healthcare Professionals caring for Children are expected to attend CEWT score training.
All registered nurses, nursing students, nursery nurses and health care assistants who perform observations in children, must attend the paediatric BLS / CEWT training every 2 years.

Where continuous electrocardiogram (ECG) and pulse oximetry are used practitioners must be trained and competent in their use and know the limitations and risks associated with these devices. All staff undertaking observations must have training in the use of the CEWT. Registered nurses must comply with NMC standards for maintaining their knowledge and skills (NMC 2015).
Assessing, performing and recording vital signs in children
Prior to performing the child's observations their psychological needs should be recognised and appropriate action taken.
Visual observation, palpation (touch), listening and communication, are used when assessing and measuring observations. This includes eliciting and taking note of the views of parents / carers.
Clear explanation should be given to parents / carers and where possible the child, concerning performance of observations and the data collected.
The child and /or parent /carer should consent to the performance and measurement of observations. Where a child under 16 is unaccompanied, local policies should be followed.
Where appropriate, the child and parent/ carer should assist the practitioner in performing and measuring of observations.
The child must be positioned correctly and comfortably prior to the procedure.
Actions to restrain the child must comply with best practice guidance.
Respiratory rate
The respiratory rate must be plotted as a dot on the chart as well as numerically.
Respirations must be counted for one minute.
The pattern, effort and rate of breathing must be observed.
Skin colour must be observed.
Abdominal movements must be counted for children less than seven years of age because these children are predominately abdominal breathers.
Signs of respiratory distress e.g. nasal flaring, grunting, wheezing, dyspnoea, recession, use of accessory and intercostal muscles, chest shape and movement should be noted by looking and listening.
Respiratory rates must not be recorded from monitoring equipment.
Saturation monitoring

Pulse Oximetry measures the oxygen saturation of Haemoglobin in arterial blood – an indirect measure of oxygen bound to Haemoglobin. Most patients will have oxygen saturation of 95% or above. A level of below 95% is clinically significant.
Oxygen saturation significantly below 90% requires urgent attention.

In children with chronic respiratory disease or cyanotic congenital heart disease, usual level of saturation may be towards the lower ranges. If this is the case, this needs to be clearly identified in the patients' notes.
Levels of oxygen should be recorded using a fully operational pulse oximeter and should be documented on the Children's Observation chart.
The oxygen saturations may be inaccurate in children with poor peripheral perfusion.

If the device does not record a saturation level, it may be that the device is faulty or not properly connected or the patient's peripheral circulation is inadequate. This should be noted and escalated to the Registered Nurse designated to that patient. The Registered Nurse must then seek senior nursing and/or medical advice. Also see Section 15.
Oxygen saturation monitors must not be used for assessment of heart rates.
The practitioner must understand the use and limitations of using oxygen saturation monitoring.
A child who is wriggling or moving may cause movement artefact which can render measurements inaccurate.
When using continuous oxygen saturation monitoring alarm parameters must be set and checked each shift. The nurse must respond to an alarm immediately and check to identify the cause.
Disposable probes are for single patient use only.
Probe sites must be checked and changed at least four hourly for pressure sores if using continuous oxygen saturation monitoring.
Heart rate
The heart rate must be plotted as a dot on the chart as well as numerically.
Where possible ensure the child is settled before measuring the heart rate.
The heart rate can be measured by:
Palpation of a central (Brachial or femoral in infants, carotid or femoral in children) or peripheral pulse (the radial pulse is the commonest site) or
Auscultation of the heart with a stethoscope
Heart rates must be counted for one minute.
The pulse rate should be consistent with the apex beat.
The heart rate must be auscultated:
In infants and children less than two years of age
If a peripheral pulse cannot be palpated (felt).
As well as recording the pulse rate, it is significant to note the pulse volume (how forceful the pulse is) and also pulse regularity.
Pulse irregularity should be documented in the patient's notes.

Pulse volume, although a subjective evaluation, is clinically important if there is a weak pulse volume or a very bounding pulse. Feeling a pulse is also an opportunity to feel if a patient is peripherally cool or warm and if they are sweaty – all of which may be clinically significant. It is not appropriate to record them on the chart, but may be appropriate to report them and document them in the patient's notes.

Pulse, pulse volume and peripheral clamminess and temperature are all important measures of perfusion. If there are concerns about a patient's well-being then measuring capillary refill time may be helpful.

When using an electro cardio gram (ECG) monitor for continuous heart rate monitoring the electronic data should be cross checked by auscultation or palpation at least 4 hourly or immediately if level of consciousness alters.
Electrodes and leads must be placed in an appropriate position and changed regularly in order to minimise the risk of damage to the infant / child's skin.
Alarm limits should be set and checked each shift.
Monitoring should not preclude manual heart rate measurement.
Blood pressure
Blood pressure must be plotted with markers (↕) not numerically.

Every child must have a blood pressure taken on admission to hospital. If the results of this are within the normal range, the frequency of further assessment will depend on the reason for admission and severity of illness.
The right arm should be used for measuring blood pressure as the pressure is generally 5mmHg greater than the left, but when this is not possible the child's lower leg can be used.
The arm should be well supported and positioned at the level of the heart.
If the forearm is higher than the heart then an underestimation will occur. Overestimation will occur if the forearm is lower than the heart
The correct size of the cuff is necessary for gaining an accurate recording.
The cuff should be wide enough to cover 2/3 of the upper arm circumference.
Cuffs too narrow results in overestimation whilst too large results in underestimation.
The cuff bladder length should cover 80 - 100% of the circumference of the arm.
The cuff must be applied so that:
Its lower border is two finger breadths above the elbow crease, except in infants.
The arrow on the cuff lines up with the brachial pulse
Sucking, crying and eating can influence the blood pressure measurements and should be noted.
Movement can affect the accuracy of automated blood pressure monitors.
The first reading of automated monitors should be disregarded, allow one to two minutes before repeating the measurement (Blood Pressure Association).
Blood pressure readings from an electronic non invasive device are less accurate at either end of the high / low spectrum. If a blood pressure reading is consistently
high / low on an automated monitor over a period of time it should be re-measured using a manual non-mercury sphygmomanometer.
Manual blood pressure should be documented exactly the same as any other blood pressure with manual written in the column, to distinguish between the two.

Although Blood Pressure is important to monitor in patients, it does tend to be a late sign of clinical deterioration. Sick patients can physiologically compensate and only fail to maintain their Blood Pressure when they are very sick.
Capillary refill time
Capillary refill time should be documented on the Children's Observation chart.

Measuring capillary refill time is recommended when assessing the circulation of sick children (RCN 2017). The capillary refill time is the rate at which blood returns to the capillary bed after it has been compressed digitally.
The capillary refill time should be assessed using the skin of the forehead, chest (sternum) or peripheral digits. The forehead and sternum are the preferred sites.
If peripheral digits are used, the practitioner should elevate the hand to the level of the heart.
Pressure should be applied for five seconds then released.
The practitioner should count the time in seconds that it takes for the skin to return to its normal colour.
The skin normally re-perfuses in less than two seconds in children
The choice of site used to assess capillary refill time and the time taken for the skin to return to its normal colour should be documented.
If it is extended beyond that time then it indicates poor perfusion. A capillary refill time of greater than 3 seconds is likely to be clinically significant.
Urine output
Medical staff and registered nurses are required to assess the need for fluid balance monitoring and this should be documented in the patient's notes.
The Children's 24 hour fluid balance chart should be used for patients' whose fluid balance is being monitored this must be accurately completed.

Inpatients who require fluid balance monitoring (cardiac, renal, post surgical, trauma, acutely unwell), the nurse must chart volume administered (orally, enterally, intravenously) AND measurement of volume lost (urine, drains, nasogastric
aspirates). Overall balance should be calculated at least every 24 hours and cumulatively over several days in children with renal failure.
Any patient with urine output of less than 0.5-1ml per kg per  hours should have their fluid balance monitored and a plan in place to manage their hydration.
A fall in urine output may be clinically significant. If there are concerns about urine output, close observation and recording of urine output is essential. Catheterisation should be considered.
If the urine output is being monitored, then an hourly output of zero requires a check that the catheter is patent as outflow obstruction should always be excluded in totally anuric patients.
A daily weight should be recorded (at the same time) to assess fluid balance, for cardiac children on the wards receiving diuretic therapy, or children with renal failure.
Temperature

The importance of temperature is well known for pyrexia but is often ignored when the temperature is falling. If there is a downward trend in temperature, this is often highly significant. Many patients with sepsis or severe infection may become hypothermic. Currently this often goes unnoticed. Falling temperature is particularly important when associated with falling blood pressure and reduced urine output.
A child's temperature must be taken on admission to hospital and at least 12 hourly or more frequently as clinically indicated unless overridden by local protocol.

If the temperature is high on admission consider antipyretic treatment if the child is irritable or restless due to the fever. There is no need to administer antipyretics for all febrile children. Measure on an hourly basis until it is resolved.
A child's temperature should be assessed if the child feels hot or cold to touch.

The temperature must be measured at least every 4 hours if the child is receiving IV therapy (drug or fluid), has a potential site of infection such as chest drain, wound etc., or has a central line in situ.
There must be clear guidance for practitioners on the accurate use of the equipment available in each organisation for measurement of temperature in children.
Mercury thermometers are hazardous and should not be used.

Oral and rectal routes should not be routinely used to measure the body temperature in children aged between 0 – 5 years (NICE 2019). A tympanic membrane thermometer or axilla thermometer or electronic / chemical dot thermometer should routinely be used.
In infants under the age of four weeks axillary temperature should be measured using an electronic thermometer in the axilla.
The thermometer should be left in position for sufficient time to gain an accurate reading according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Neurological assessment

Neurological status is an important marker of deterioration in clinical condition. Changes in neurological status are highly significant. There are particular difficulties with assessing neurology at night. Sleep and unconsciousness are not the same but may look similar. If a patient requires close neurological monitoring then an appropriate age Glasgow Coma chart should be used (although CEWT Scoring may be indicated too). For normal purposes a simple AVPU score (see 20.4) is adequate.
Any reduction in consciousness level is significant and may be an early indication of deterioration and should always be reported to the registered nurse.
AVPU is an essential element of the CEWT score observations. It is not a replacement for the Glasgow Coma Scale. AVPU or GCS should be recorded but not both.
The AVPU is a coma score. As part of the initial assessment on admission of a child to the ward the practitioner should assess if the child is:
The child must be woken to perform this observation to ensure an assessment of their conscious level is made.
If the child does not respond to verbal stimulation or touch in infants, the practitioner must assess the child's airway, breathing and circulation and call for assistance.
A formal Glasgow Coma Score should be undertaken for any child who is not alert unless there is evidence that this is the child's normal condition.
Tracheostomy

Children with tracheotomies should be nursed in an area where they can be easily seen by healthcare staff. If the child is not being directly observed by a healthcare professional or parent/guardian then careful consideration should be given to the level of monitoring required, particularly for infants (Less than 1 year), or those with specific clinical concerns (e.g. children with poor head control or at risk of self- decannulation). Pulse oximetry should be used if clinically indicated.
Acute pain service (APS)

The children's Pain/Sedation and Nausea Measurement tool is available for reference for use with all children. All patients prescribed analgesia must be assessed using this tool and documented on the Children's observation chart.
Paediatric sepsis

The CEWT score can be used to support the screening and identification of children with suspected sepsis. If the CEWT has triggered and you suspect sepsis please follow the escalation process according to the CEWT escalation aid and the sepsis screening and action tool.

It is acknowledged that not all children with suspected sepsis will trigger on the CEWT scoring system and use of the “sepsis screening and action tool” should be considered in cases where sepsis is suspected at triage or subsequently during care provision.

“Severe tachypnea” and “severe tachycardia” are red flag symptoms for children with suspected sepsis. Consider the parameters defined on the sepsis screening and action tools for age specific guidance on what constitutes severe tachypnoea and severe tachycardia.

“Moderate tachypnea” and “Moderate tachycardia” are amber flag symptoms for children with suspected sepsis. Consider the parameters defined on the “sepsis screening and action tools” for age specific guidance on what constitutes moderate tachypnoea and moderate tachycardia.
Equality impact assessment
This Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
Infection prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection control by ensuring that they effectively decontaminate their hands between each patient.
All observation monitoring equipment will be decontaminated between each patient and disposable attachments used where supplied.

Where patients are high risk of infection, disposable monitoring equipment should be used for single patient use. Disposable equipment should be disposed of as per Trust policy, and any non-disposable equipment should be decontaminated as per Trust policy.
Monitoring and audit
Any instances of non-compliance with this policy should be recorded on a risk event form in accordance with the Incident Policy.

An audit of compliance with this policy will be undertaken quarterly by Clinical Nurse Facilitators and/or Lead Nurses, co-ordinated by Clinical Audit in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and policy. The audit will assess compliance with:
the requirement to record frequency of observations;
documentation of appropriate observations;
CEWT scoring;
Escalation processes.

Findings from the audit will be reported to the Heads of Nursing, the Paediatric Urgent & Emergency Group and the Deteriorating Patient Group. An action plan with identified leads and timescales will be developed and approved by representatives from these groups. Progress with implementation of the actions will be monitored by these groups.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Paediatric Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Paediatric Practice Steering Group and appropriate Paediatric Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
